title: Call It Stormy Monday (But Tuesday Is Just as Bad)

musicalLanguage.description: T-Bone Walker's 1947 classic is the gold standard for slow, sophisticated blues. Unlike basic 12-bar blues, Stormy Monday uses jazzy 9th chords and a turnaround that passes through unusual changes. The slow tempo demands expressive phrasing — every note must count.
musicalLanguage.structure: 12-bar blues with jazz substitutions. This excerpt: first 8 bars
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: G9 — the rich 9th chord sets this apart from basic blues immediately
Bar 3-4: G9 continues with melodic embellishments — slow and expressive
Bar 5-6: C9 (IV chord) — same lush voicing moved to the subdominant
Bar 7-8: Return to G9 — the melody weeps and sighs
teachingGoals: 9th chord voicings — richer than basic dominant 7ths
Slow blues phrasing — stretching time, bending the beat
Dynamic control at slow tempos — every note has weight
styleTips: This is SLOW — do not rush. Let every note breathe and decay.
The 9th chords give a sophisticated, jazzy color. Lean into them.
Think of a vocalist on every melody note — where would they breathe?

measures.teachingNote: G9 — the 9th chord (G-B-D-F-A). Left hand plays root + shell. The 9th (A) on top adds color.

measures.leftHand: G2:q B2 F3:q G2:q B2 F3:q
measures.teachingNote: G9 — melody descends through the chord. Take your time. This is the blues at its most expressive.
G9 — the Bb grace note sliding into B is the blue note smear. Essential blues technique.
G9 — more blue note movement. The Bb-B slide appears again. It is the voice of the blues.

measures.leftHand: C3:q E3 Bb3:q C3:q E3 Bb3:q
measures.teachingNote: C9 — same 9th voicing on the IV chord. The 9th (D) and b7 (Bb) give it richness.
C9 — melody descends through the IV chord. Same expressive approach.

measures.leftHand: G2:q B2 F3:q G2:q B2 F3:q
measures.teachingNote: G9 — back home. The 9th (A) is the resolution note. Let it hang in the air.
G9 — ascending run building toward the V chord. The blue note Bb slides into B again.
